title: Psalms Chapter 51 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 51 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 51 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 51.

questions.question: Who is the author of Psalms 51 according to the chapter text?
questions.correctAnswer: David
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:1 states, 'A Psalm of David,' indicating he is the author.

questions.question: According to Psalms 51:1, who came to David after he had gone in to Bathsheba?
questions.correctAnswer: Nathan the prophet
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:1 mentions Nathan the prophet came unto David after he had gone in to Bathsheba.

questions.question: What does David ask God to do according to Psalms 51:2?
options: Wash me thoroughly from mine iniquity
questions.correctAnswer: Wash me thoroughly from mine iniquity
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:2 says, 'Wash me throughly from mine iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 51:5, how was David shaped?
questions.correctAnswer: In iniquity
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:5 states, 'Behold, I was shapen in iniquity; and in sin did my mother conceive me.'

questions.question: What does David ask God to create in him in Psalms 51:10?
questions.correctAnswer: A clean heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:10 says, 'Create in me a clean heart, O God; and renew a right spirit within me.'

questions.question: What does David ask God not to take from him in Psalms 51:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Thy holy spirit
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:11 states, 'Cast me not away from thy presence; and take not thy holy spirit from me.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 51:12, what does David ask God to restore unto him?
questions.correctAnswer: The joy of thy salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:12 says, 'Restore unto me the joy of thy salvation; and uphold me with thy free spirit.'

questions.question: What will David do if God restores him according to Psalms 51:13?
questions.correctAnswer: Teach transgressors God's ways
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:13 states, 'Then will I teach transgressors thy ways; and sinners shall be converted unto thee.'

questions.question: In Psalms 51:14, from what does David ask God to deliver him?
questions.correctAnswer: Bloodguiltiness
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:14 says, 'Deliver me from bloodguiltiness, O God, thou God of my salvation.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 51:16, what does God not desire?
questions.correctAnswer: Sacrifice
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:16 states, 'For thou desirest not sacrifice; else would I give it.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 51:17, what does God value as a sacrifice?
options: A broken spirit and contrite heart
questions.correctAnswer: A broken spirit and contrite heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:17 says, 'The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit: a broken and a contrite heart, O God, thou wilt not despise.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 51:7 says 'Purge me with hyssop, and I shall be clean.'
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:7 states, 'Purge me with hyssop, and I shall be clean.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 51:15 says 'O Lord, open thou my lips; and my mouth shall shew forth thy praise.'
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:15 states exactly, 'O Lord, open thou my lips; and my mouth shall shew forth thy praise.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 51:4, David sinned against many people, not God alone.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:4 says, 'Against thee, thee only, have I sinned,' indicating David sinned against God alone.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 51:8: 'Make me to hear joy and gladness; that the bones which thou hast ______ may rejoice.'
questions.correctAnswer: broken
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:8 states, 'Make me to hear joy and gladness; that the bones which thou hast broken may rejoice.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 51 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 51 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels weighed down by guilt and asks how to find cleansing. Based on Psalms 51, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God can wash away all sin and cleanse us completely.
We must first earn forgiveness through good works.
Ignoring sin will help us forget it.
questions.correctAnswer: God can wash away all sin and cleanse us completely.
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:2 says, 'Wash me throughly from mine iniquity, and cleanse me from my sin.' This shows that God’s mercy can cleanse sin, supported by verses 7 and 10 which emphasize purification and a clean heart.

questions.question: How does Psalms 51 teach about humility in approaching God after sinning?
options: Confessing our sins and acknowledging we have sinned against God alone.
Boasting about our good deeds to gain favor.
Ignoring our sins to maintain confidence.
questions.correctAnswer: Confessing our sins and acknowledging we have sinned against God alone.
questions.explanation: Verse 4 emphasizes personal responsibility and humility: 'Against thee, thee only, have I sinned.' Confession and humility before God are key themes throughout verses 3-5.

questions.question: A believer struggles with ongoing temptation and feels born into weakness. What encouragement does Psalms 51 offer?
options: Recognize that sinfulness is part of our human condition but seek God’s wisdom and renewal.
Give up because sin is unavoidable.
Depend solely on self-discipline without God’s help.
Avoid prayer as it won’t change our nature.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize that sinfulness is part of our human condition but seek God’s wisdom and renewal.
questions.explanation: Verse 5 acknowledges being 'shapen in iniquity,' but verses 6 and 10 encourage seeking truth, wisdom, and a clean heart from God.

questions.question: What does Psalms 51 teach about the role of the heart and spirit in spiritual renewal?
options: God desires a clean heart and a right spirit within us.
External rituals are more important than inner change.
Only sacrifices can renew the spirit.
God overlooks the condition of the heart if we appear religious.
questions.correctAnswer: God desires a clean heart and a right spirit within us.
questions.explanation: Verse 10 prays for a 'clean heart' and 'a right spirit,' emphasizing inner transformation over external acts, supported also by verse 17.

questions.question: A believer feels distant from God after sinning. How does Psalms 51 encourage us to respond in prayer?
options: Ask God not to cast us away and to restore His Spirit within us.
Accept that God has abandoned us.
Try to fix things without God’s help.
Stop praying since God is displeased.
questions.correctAnswer: Ask God not to cast us away and to restore His Spirit within us.
questions.explanation: Verses 11 and 12 plead with God not to take away His Spirit and to restore joy and uphold with His free Spirit, showing prayer as a means to restoration.

questions.question: How does Psalms 51 model evangelism and sharing the Gospel after experiencing God’s forgiveness?
options: Teaching transgressors God’s ways and leading sinners to repentance.
Ignoring the need for others to repent.
questions.correctAnswer: Teaching transgressors God’s ways and leading sinners to repentance.
questions.explanation: Verse 13 commits to teaching sinners God’s ways and helping convert them, showing that personal forgiveness leads to active witness.

questions.question: According to Psalms 51, what kind of sacrifice does God truly desire?
options: A broken spirit and a contrite heart.
questions.correctAnswer: A broken spirit and a contrite heart.
questions.explanation: Verse 17 states, 'The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit: a broken and a contrite heart,' indicating God values sincere repentance over ritual sacrifice.

questions.question: How does Psalms 51 encourage integrity and honesty in our relationship with God?
options: Acknowledging sins openly and asking for mercy.
Relying on sacrifices alone to cover sins.
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledging sins openly and asking for mercy.
questions.explanation: Verses 1-4 show David openly confessing his transgressions and seeking God’s mercy, modeling honesty and integrity in prayer.

questions.question: What does Psalms 51 teach about perseverance through trials related to sin and guilt?
options: Continue seeking God’s forgiveness and restoration despite feeling broken.
Punish oneself harshly without seeking God.
questions.correctAnswer: Continue seeking God’s forgiveness and restoration despite feeling broken.
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 and 12 reveal David’s ongoing plea for cleansing and joy, encouraging perseverance in prayer during spiritual trials.

questions.question: A believer wants to know how to maintain joy after repentance. What does Psalms 51 advise?
options: Trust in God’s salvation and ask Him to restore joy and uphold with His Spirit.
Rely solely on feelings of happiness.
Focus only on avoiding sin without rejoicing.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God’s salvation and ask Him to restore joy and uphold with His Spirit.
questions.explanation: Verse 12 says, 'Restore unto me the joy of thy salvation; and uphold me with thy free spirit,' highlighting the source of joy is God’s sustaining presence.

questions.question: How does Psalms 51 encourage believers to live out humility and gratitude in daily life?
options: By acknowledging our need for God's mercy and praising Him with honest lips.
By neglecting praise because actions are enough.
questions.correctAnswer: By acknowledging our need for God's mercy and praising Him with honest lips.
questions.explanation: Verses 15 and 1 show a heart that seeks mercy and desires to praise God openly, reflecting humility and gratitude.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 51, God delights primarily in burnt offerings and sacrifices as a way to receive forgiveness.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 16 and 17 clarify that God does not desire sacrifices or burnt offerings primarily, but a broken spirit and contrite heart.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 51 teaches that God’s forgiveness leads to a transformed life that impacts others.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 13 indicates that experiencing God’s forgiveness leads to teaching transgressors and converting sinners, showing transformation and witness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Create in me a ______ heart, O God; and renew a right spirit within me.'
questions.correctAnswer: clean
questions.explanation: Verse 10 directly states the request for a 'clean heart' and a right spirit, emphasizing inner renewal.

questions.question: How does Psalms 51 relate to the practical Christian virtue of forgiveness and reconciliation?
options: It models confessing sin, seeking God’s mercy, and then teaching others to turn away from sin.
It encourages hiding sin to avoid shame.
It suggests reconciliation happens without repentance.
It prioritizes ritual over heart change.
questions.correctAnswer: It models confessing sin, seeking God’s mercy, and then teaching others to turn away from sin.
questions.explanation: Verses 1-4 and 13 show confession, mercy seeking, and then leading others to repentance, highlighting forgiveness and reconciliation.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 51 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 51.

questions.question: In Psalms 51:5, David confesses that he was shaped in iniquity. How does this verse reflect the doctrine of original sin found elsewhere in Scripture?
options: It aligns with Romans 5:12, indicating sin entered the world through one man
It contradicts the idea of original sin by emphasizing individual responsibility
It reflects only David's personal failures, not a universal human condition
It supports the concept that sin is only a social construct
questions.correctAnswer: It aligns with Romans 5:12, indicating sin entered the world through one man
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:5 states David was 'shapen in iniquity,' which parallels Romans 5:12 where Paul explains sin entered through one man, Adam, indicating a theological connection about inherent sinfulness.

questions.question: What literary device is predominantly used in Psalms 51:10, 'Create in me a clean heart, O God; and renew a right spirit within me,' and what is its significance?
options: Chiasm, highlighting the reversal of sin to purity
Metaphor, comparing the heart to a physical object
Allegory, representing the nation of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism, emphasizing internal spiritual renewal
questions.explanation: This verse employs synonymous parallelism common in Hebrew poetry, repeating the idea of inner renewal to stress sincere repentance and spiritual cleansing.

questions.question: In Psalms 51:7, David asks to be purged with hyssop. What is the historical and cultic significance of hyssop in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: Hyssop was used in purification rituals, such as in Exodus 12 for the Passover
Hyssop was a symbol of royal authority in ancient Israel
Hyssop was a common incense burned in temples
Hyssop was used to anoint kings during coronation ceremonies
questions.correctAnswer: Hyssop was used in purification rituals, such as in Exodus 12 for the Passover
questions.explanation: Hyssop was a plant used in cleansing rituals, notably to apply lamb's blood during Passover (Exodus 12:22), symbolizing purification and atonement, which David invokes metaphorically here.

questions.question: According to Psalms 51:17, what kind of sacrifices does God desire, and how does this contrast with external ritual sacrifices?
options: A broken spirit and contrite heart, rather than burnt offerings
Bullocks and sheep, as prescribed in Levitical law
questions.correctAnswer: A broken spirit and contrite heart, rather than burnt offerings
questions.explanation: This verse highlights that God values inward repentance ('broken spirit and contrite heart') over mere external rituals, signifying a deeper spiritual requirement beyond the Levitical sacrifices.

questions.question: How does Psalms 51:12's request to 'Restore unto me the joy of thy salvation' connect to New Testament themes of joy in salvation?
options: It anticipates the joy described in Philippians 4:4 of rejoicing in the Lord always
It contradicts New Testament teachings on salvation
It focuses solely on Old Testament ritual joy without spiritual significance
It refers exclusively to national restoration, not individual salvation
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates the joy described in Philippians 4:4 of rejoicing in the Lord always
questions.explanation: The Psalmist's plea for restored joy in salvation prefigures New Testament exhortations, such as Philippians 4:4, where believers are called to rejoice continually in the Lord.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 51:4 emphasizes that David's sin was primarily against God, serving to justify God's judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:4 explicitly states David sinned 'against thee, thee only,' highlighting that God is the ultimate judge and justification for His judgments is upheld.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most directly echoes the theme of inward cleansing found in Psalms 51:10?
options: Ezekiel 36:26, where God promises a new heart and spirit
questions.correctAnswer: Ezekiel 36:26, where God promises a new heart and spirit
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:26 promises God will give a new heart and spirit, paralleling David's request in Psalms 51:10 for a clean heart and right spirit, emphasizing internal transformation.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'hide thy face from my sins' in Psalms 51:9 in the context of ancient Hebrew understanding of God's presence?
options: It implies a plea for God to turn away His judgment and not see the sin
It means God should physically cover His face
It is a request for God to punish others instead
It refers to hiding sins from human witnesses
questions.correctAnswer: It implies a plea for God to turn away His judgment and not see the sin
questions.explanation: In Hebrew thought, God's 'face' represents His presence and favor; asking Him to hide His face from sin is a request for mercy and removal of divine judgment.

questions.question: In Psalms 51:1, the term 'lovingkindness' translates the Hebrew word 'chesed.' What is the theological importance of 'chesed' in the Old Testament?
options: It denotes God's covenantal faithful love and mercy
It refers only to God's justice and wrath
It is a term for ritual purity
It describes human kindness toward each other
questions.correctAnswer: It denotes God's covenantal faithful love and mercy
questions.explanation: 'Chesed' is a central Old Testament term describing God's steadfast, faithful love rooted in covenant, which underpins David's appeal for mercy in Psalms 51:1.

questions.question: How does the structure of Psalms 51 reflect a penitential psalm, and what is its primary literary progression?
options: Confession of sin, plea for mercy, request for renewal, and commitment to teach righteousness
Lament about enemies, call for vengeance, and declaration of victory
Thanksgiving for deliverance, recounting of God's deeds, and praise
Wisdom instruction, proverbs, and ethical exhortations
questions.correctAnswer: Confession of sin, plea for mercy, request for renewal, and commitment to teach righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 51 follows the penitential psalm pattern: David confesses sin (vv. 1-6), asks for mercy and cleansing (vv. 7-12), and pledges to instruct others (vv. 13-19), illustrating his repentance and transformation.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'my tongue shall sing aloud of thy righteousness' in Psalms 51:14 foreshadow in the context of biblical worship?
options: The prophetic praise expressed in the New Testament hymns of the early church
The silence required during temple sacrifices
The cessation of all music in worship
The replacement of song by spoken prayer
questions.correctAnswer: The prophetic praise expressed in the New Testament hymns of the early church
questions.explanation: David's vow to sing of God's righteousness anticipates the joyful praise central to Christian worship, as seen in New Testament hymns and songs of praise.

questions.question: According to Psalms 51:6, God desires 'truth in the inward parts.' Which Old Testament book extensively develops this theme of God valuing internal truth over external ritual?
questions.correctAnswer: Proverbs
questions.explanation: The book of Proverbs often emphasizes the importance of inner wisdom and truth, resonating with Psalms 51:6’s focus on internal integrity over outward appearances.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 51:13 says, 'Then will I teach transgressors thy _____; and sinners shall be converted unto thee.'
questions.correctAnswer: ways
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states David will teach transgressors God's 'ways,' indicating a path of repentance and instruction after personal restoration.

questions.question: What is the significance of David addressing Nathan the prophet in the superscription of Psalms 51, and how does it frame the psalm's historical and theological context?
options: It situates the psalm after David's sin with Bathsheba, highlighting repentance prompted by prophetic confrontation
It indicates Nathan was the author of the psalm
It shows the psalm was written before David’s kingship
It suggests the psalm is unrelated to any historical event
questions.correctAnswer: It situates the psalm after David's sin with Bathsheba, highlighting repentance prompted by prophetic confrontation
questions.explanation: The superscription links the psalm to a historical moment where Nathan confronted David over his sin, giving theological depth about repentance and divine mercy.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 51:16-17 state that God delights primarily in burnt offerings rather than a contrite heart.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The verses explicitly say God does not desire sacrifice or burnt offerings as much as a broken spirit and contrite heart, emphasizing inner repentance over ritual.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 51 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 51 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 51, what is the fundamental reason David asks God to blot out his transgressions?
options: Because of God's lovingkindness and tender mercies
Because of the sacrifices David offers
questions.correctAnswer: Because of God's lovingkindness and tender mercies
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:1 explicitly states that David appeals to God's lovingkindness and tender mercies as the basis for mercy and forgiveness. This aligns with Old Testament teachings such as Exodus 34:6-7 and New Testament affirmations like Ephesians 2:4-5 and Titus 3:5, underscoring God's compassionate nature toward repentant sinners.

questions.question: What does David request God to create in him according to Psalms 51:10?
questions.correctAnswer: A clean heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:10 reveals David's plea for a clean heart and a renewed right spirit, emphasizing inward renewal. This reflects the prophetic vision in Ezekiel 36:26, the emphasis on the new heart in Jeremiah 31:33, the teaching of Jesus on purity in Matthew 5:8, and Paul’s call to holiness in 2 Corinthians 7:1.

questions.question: In Psalms 51, what does David acknowledge about his sin in relation to God?
options: He has sinned against God only
He has sinned against others only
He has sinned against the king
He has sinned against the temple
questions.correctAnswer: He has sinned against God only
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:4 states clearly that David confesses his sin is ultimately against God alone, highlighting the theological truth that sin is primarily an offense against God's holiness. This is echoed in 1 Samuel 12:7-10 and Romans 3:23, emphasizing human culpability before God.

questions.question: What does David identify as the condition of his being from birth in Psalms 51:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Shapen in iniquity
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:5 acknowledges the doctrine of original sin, where David admits a sinful nature from conception. This theme is consistent with Romans 5:12, Psalm 58:3, and Ephesians 2:3, revealing humanity's inherited sinfulness.

questions.question: What does David ask God not to take away from him in Psalms 51:11?
questions.correctAnswer: The Holy Spirit
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:11 shows David's plea for God's presence and the Holy Spirit to remain with him, underscoring the Spirit's role in sanctification. This is affirmed in John 14:16-17, Romans 8:9, and 1 Corinthians 6:19-20, highlighting the Spirit’s indwelling presence.

questions.question: What does David say is the 'sacrifice' that God truly desires in Psalms 51:17?
questions.correctAnswer: A broken and contrite heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:17 teaches that God values heartfelt repentance over ritual sacrifices, a prophetic theme consistent with Hosea 6:6, Isaiah 57:15, Matthew 9:13, and Hebrews 10:22, emphasizing sincere humility before God.

questions.question: According to Psalms 51:6, what does God desire in the inward parts?
questions.correctAnswer: Truth
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:6 expresses God's desire for inward truth and wisdom, reflecting the biblical emphasis on sincere righteousness rather than mere external compliance. This corresponds with Proverbs 3:5-6, Jeremiah 17:10, John 4:24, and Romans 12:2.

questions.question: What does David promise to do if God restores him, according to Psalms 51:13?
questions.correctAnswer: Teach transgressors God's ways
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:13 reveals David's commitment to instruct others in God's ways upon his restoration, highlighting the transformative power of salvation. This is consistent with the Great Commission (Matthew 28:19-20), and Paul's ministry in Acts 20:20.

questions.question: What does David ask for in Psalms 51:12 to replace the joy he has lost?
questions.correctAnswer: The joy of salvation
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:12 shows David’s desire for the restoration of salvation's joy, emphasizing God's role in renewing the believer's spirit. This is echoed in Nehemiah 8:10, Isaiah 61:10, Romans 15:13, and 1 Peter 1:8.

questions.question: What does David ask God to do with his sins in Psalms 51:9?
options: Hide Thy face and blot out all iniquities
questions.correctAnswer: Hide Thy face and blot out all iniquities
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:9 captures David’s plea for God to remove the evidence of sin by hiding His face and blotting out iniquities, illustrating divine forgiveness. Similar themes appear in Isaiah 43:25, Micah 7:19, Hebrews 8:12, and 1 John 1:9.

questions.question: Which metaphor does David use in Psalms 51:7 to describe cleansing from sin?
options: Purge me with hyssop and I shall be whiter than snow
Wash me with oil and anoint me
Cleanse me with fire and brimstone
Purify me with water and blood
questions.correctAnswer: Purge me with hyssop and I shall be whiter than snow
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:7 uses the hyssop cleansing ritual to symbolize purification, a motif seen in Leviticus 14:4-7, Exodus 12:22, John 19:29, and 1 John 1:7, highlighting the symbolic and spiritual cleansing from sin.

questions.question: What does David say will happen to his tongue if God delivers him from bloodguiltiness in Psalms 51:14?
options: It shall sing aloud of God's righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: It shall sing aloud of God's righteousness
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:14 promises that deliverance leads to praise, aligning with biblical themes in Psalm 34:1, Isaiah 12:5, Hebrews 13:15, and Revelation 5:9, where salvation inspires worship and testimony.

questions.question: How does Psalms 51 describe the role of the Spirit in the believer's restoration (Psalms 51:12)?
options: To uphold with Thy free spirit
questions.correctAnswer: To uphold with Thy free spirit
questions.explanation: In Psalms 51:12, the Spirit is portrayed as sustaining and empowering the believer, reflecting themes in John 14:26, Romans 8:11, Galatians 5:22-23, and 2 Corinthians 3:17 about the Spirit's role in sanctification and comfort.

questions.question: What is the ultimate purpose of God's judgment according to David's confession in Psalms 51:4?
options: That God might be justified and clear when He judges
questions.correctAnswer: That God might be justified and clear when He judges
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:4 states that sin against God serves to justify His judgment, emphasizing God's righteousness and justice. This is consistent with Romans 3:4, Psalm 19:9, Revelation 16:7, and Isaiah 45:21, portraying God's judicial integrity.

questions.question: In Psalms 51, what does David ask God to do to his broken bones (Psalms 51:8)?
questions.correctAnswer: Make them rejoice
questions.explanation: Psalms 51:8 uses the metaphor of broken bones to signify affliction, asking God for restoration and joy. This imagery aligns with Psalm 34:18, Isaiah 61:3, John 11:25, and 2 Corinthians 1:3-7, which connect suffering with divine comfort and renewal.
